did.abstract: John Brademas (1927-2016) was born and raised in Indiana, and later represented the Third District of Indiana in the United States House of Representatives from 1959 to 1980. After leaving public office, Brademas accepted the position of President of New York University (NYU), serving from 1981 to 1992. The Records of the Office of the President (John Brademas) contain files related to the daily administration of the office of the President. Records in this collection include Brademas' daily schedule; event material; speeches; correspondence; funder and institution subject files; Board of Trustees material; reports and communications on NYU Schools and Divisions; files on student groups; audiovisual recordings of speeches and events; and publicity material.
did.physloc: Some materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p:
University Archives staff will review all requested material before providing access.
Administrative records and unpublished reports of New York University are closed for a period of 20 years from the date of their creation. Access to files spanning multiple years will be opened to researchers based on the date of the most recent materials. Board of Trustees records are closed for 35 years from the date of creation. Materials related to personnel, grievances, job and fellowship searches and applications, and all files that fall under the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) are permanently restricted. Additional restrictions may apply to other materials in this collection. For questions regarding specific restrictions, please contact the University Archives.
Individual restricted files in open series are notated in the file title (e.g., "Correspondence RESTRICTED"), physically separated, and stored in shared restricted boxes.
Series VII. Governance files are closed until December 31, 2027.
The following series are closed and access is restricted:
Series IV. Development
Series VI. Finance
Series XIV. Correspondence

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Materials were transferred in multiple accessions. The accession numbers associated with this collection are 12.009, 12.017, 13.002, 13.029, 13.040, 13.041, 14.002, 14.006, 2016.003, 2016.040, 2017.004, 2017.005, 2017.045, 2017.048, 2019.041, and 2022.043.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p:
On 1/21/2020, three cartons of duplicate material were removed and shredded as previously agreed upon by the University Archivist.
On 2/2020, one carton of audiovisual material and one carton of NYU publications were removed from the collection, deaccessioned, and sent back to the University Archivist.
On 2/27/2020, 21 boxes of personnel files were removed from the collection, deaccessioned, and shredded.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Material was not arranged by the processing archivist, but remains in the order in which it was received.
The records are arranged into 14 series. The series arrangement of the records is as follows:

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Stephen John Brademas, Jr. (1927-2016) was born in Mishawaka, Indiana to Beatrice Goble Brademas, a schoolteacher, and Stephen John Brademas, Sr., a Greek-immigrant restaurateur. Brademas graduated from South Bend Central High School and entered the University of Notre Dame in 1945, but soon left to join the Navy where he was appointed to the Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps until May 1946. In September of that year, he entered Harvard College and in 1949 graduated with a B.A. in Government. From 1950 to 1953, he studied as a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University, England, where he received a Doctor of Philosophy in Social Studies.
From 1959 to 1980, Brademas represented the Third District of Indiana in the United States House of Representatives. He served on the Education and Labor Committee, the House Administration Committee, and the Joint Committee on the Library of Congress. Brademas played a principal role in writing major legislation concerning all forms of education, including elementary, collegiate, and vocational training. He was also a major proponent of legislation for services for the elderly and handicapped, as well as Federal support for cultural institutions and the arts. In January 1973, Brademas was appointed Chief Deputy Majority Whip and in 1977 was appointed Majority Whip, a position he held for the next four years.
After leaving public office, Brademas accepted the position of President of New York University (NYU), serving from 1981 to 1992. During his tenure, he worked to change NYU from a primarily commuter school by facilitating the construction or purchase of 11 residence halls, which by the time he left, housed 44 percent of the NYU student population. Under his guidance, NYU also added new academic programs including the Onassis Center for Hellenic Studies and the Skirball Department of Hebrew and Judaic Studies. During his tenure, Brademas established NYU programs in Cyprus, Egypt, France, Israel and Japan. In July of 1990, he announced his resignation and officially stepped down from his position, becoming president emeritus in 1992 after a sabbatical.
After leaving NYU, Brademas served as chairman of the President's Committee on the Arts and the Humanities from 1994 to 2001. From 2004 to 2007, he was a member of the New York State Board of Regents. In 2005, NYU established the John Brademas Center of New York University, a research and teaching facility. He was the recipient of more than 50 honorary degrees and awards, many conferred by European governments or cultural organizations. Brademas passed away in 2016.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact the University Archives, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596 with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Records of the Office of the President (John Brademas); RG 3.0.10; box number; folder number or item identifier; New York University Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p:
Decisions regarding arrangement interventions for this collection prior to 2018 are not yet recorded. During this same time, sections of the material were refoldered and an inventory was created.
In 2019 memorabilia was rehoused by Preservation and sent to offsite storage. During the processing of this collection, the remaining material was foldered and previously overstuffed folders were separated and refoldered. Original titles were transcribed onto the new folders when possible. All material was placed in appropriately sized containers. Audiovisual material was removed and boxed separately. Previously untitled and undated files were provided more description and dates, while any new file titles were added to the end of the inventory within each series.
File titles were reviewed by the processing archivist and when identified as restricted, were physically separated, notated in the file title (e.g., "Correspondence RESTRICTED"), physically separated, and stored in shared restricted boxes.
One carton of audiovisual material, four cartons of paper, and 22 boxes of personnel files were removed and deaccessioned from the collection. Twenty-five containers of material were separated from this collection and transferred to other NYU special collections.
Folder titles in the Development Series were not published in the finding aid due to personal information.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For additional material on John Brademas, see also: the John Brademas Personal Papers (MC 241) and the John Brademas Congressional Papers (MC 168).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
The collection contains records of New York University's 13th President John Brademas who served from 1981 to 1991. Files created by Brademas' office contain material related to the responsibilities of this position, including public appearances and events; contact with various NYU Schools and Divisions staff; interaction with student groups and representatives; and fostering NYU's relationships with various governmental departments and other organizations as they relate to funding and/or educational policy for universities.
Files in this collection include Brademas' speeches and remarks; NYU Board meeting material; and public relations event planning files which include video recordings related to NYU's acquisition of the La Pietra villa. Additionally, this collection contains internal and external communications, reports, and meeting notes related to NYU facilities, NYU Schools and Divisions, and student groups. Files accumulated by Brademas on individuals, organizations, and companies document his relationships cultivated for the purpose of fundraising, educational policy support, and NYU program development. Although a selection of Brademas' chronological correspondence has its own series, a significant amount of topical correspondence can be found throughout the entire collection.
Pre-1981 office files in this collection were likely a carry-over from the previous President's office and used for reference by Brademas and his staff. Material dated beyond Brademas' term found in this collection covers projects he continued for NYU working as president emeritus, after officially leaving office in 1991.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Two record cartons of photographs were transferred to the New York University Archives collection (PHOTO 00001); 21 boxes of files were transferred to the John Brademas Personal Papers (MC 241); one record carton of files was transferred to the John Brademas Congressional Papers (MC 168); and one record carton of files was transferred to the Records of the Office of the President (Dr. James McNaughton Hester) (RG 3.0.7).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by John Brademas and the Office of the President are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the New York University Archives. Please contact the New York University Archives, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Brademas' appointment books from 1981 to 1991, documenting his daily events and meetings. Other files include material related to the Bobst Award; honorary degrees; selection process for departmental chairs and visiting professors; fundraising; and university program development. Information on NYU's overseas programs; the Urban Studies and Research Center; the Grey Art Gallery; and the Japanese Business Center are in this series. The "JB Project" files appear to be ideas fostered by Brademas, including a Chinese University Presidents' group visit to NYU and a potential Latin American Foreign Ministers Conference. Brademas' travel briefing books in this series were created for his trips taken between 1989 to 1990 to Greece, Cyprus, and France. These briefing books typically contain schedules, support material for meetings, and profiles on people he would meet during the trip. Similar travel briefing material can also be found in Series VII.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains files collected by Brademas on organizations he regularly interacted with or served in some capacity. The files typically contain organization reports, publications, correspondence, and meeting notes. Organizations with files containing a significant amount of material include the American Academy of Arts and Sciences; Academy for Educational Development; American Council on Education; Association of American Universities; Association of Colleges and Universities of New York; Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities; Federal Reserve Bank; Onassis Foundation; United Way; and the Rockefeller Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains files related to NYU's fundraising efforts, dating from 1980 to 1991. Files include financial reports; fundraising campaign material for NYU Schools and Divisions; travel material; and files on individuals and groups. This series also contains alphabetical correspondence files related to funding projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains files related to facilities and services maintained by NYU, including memos, letters, and reports dating from 1965 to 1990. Topics include security, recycling, the Cole Sports Center, residence halls, real estate, and food service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the files in this series are NYU Board of Trustees material dating from 1980 to 1990, including meeting minutes and agendas, President's Reports, committee information, individual member files, and Presidents' Congratulatory files. This series also contains files related to Brademas' trips to Japan, Asia, Poland, Spain, South America, and Yugoslavia on behalf of NYU, which would often involve Board of Trustees members. University Senate meeting files found in this series date from 1980 to 1991 and usually contain minutes, reports, correspondence, and agendas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, reports, budgets, and publications accumulated by the President's office from federal and state government departments and agencies which impacted NYU during the 1980s and early 1990s. Material dates from 1965 to 1990 and contains information on specific federal departments including the Department of Labor; Department of Defense; and Department of the Interior, as well as agencies including U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD); National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA); and the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA). Files in this series also contain information generated by the U.S. House of Representatives, the Senate, and New York State Senate and Assembly. Additionally, this series includes subject files containing reports and other publications on student loans, taxes, and drugs in schools.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series mainly contains public relations office material related to appearances and events Brademas attended or organized while serving as President of NYU. Files in this series contain requests for Brademas appearances and speeches; planning files for NYU events; and correspondence. A small collection of speeches in this series date from 1981 to 1984; however, a more comprehensive set can be found in Series XIII. Planning files for events hosted in Brademas' penthouse residence are in this series and typically include invitation lists, menus, and schedules. Clippings and press releases in this series feature Brademas and his connection to NYU. Photographic portraits of Brademas, as well as event photographs are in this series. Event photographs include parties at the Onassis Center in Greece, and Brademas' trips to Asia. A large number of video recordings in this series contain footage for a possible informational video for NYU's Villa La Pietra in Florence, Italy. These videos contain interviews with Sir Harold Acton, views of the building and grounds, and historical stock footage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes reports, speeches, correspondence, budgets, and annual reports collected by the Office of the President on individual NYU Schools and Divisions. Groups with the largest amount of material include the College of Arts and Sciences; College of Dentistry; Medical Center; Tisch School of the Arts; College and Graduate School of Business Administration; School of Education, Health, Nursing, and Arts Professions; Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences; School of Law; School of Continuing Education; and Institute of Fine Arts. This series also contains files on NYU in Spain; the Gallatin Division; La Maison Franaise; Onassis Center for Hellenic Studies; and Deutsches Haus. Admissions reports on individual schools and the university date from 1977 to 1983. Meeting files for the Boards for the Medical Center, School of Arts and Science, and Law School Board are also in this series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains subjects relating to NYU students, including financial aid; housing; South African students at NYU; fraternities; sports teams; and student groups, such as the Gay Students Union. Files date from 1971 to 1991 and typically contain correspondence, reports, magazine articles, and press clippings. There are a significant number of files in this series containing admissions statistical reports and admission intervention request-related correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains John Bradmas' speeches, writings, and interviews while serving as President of NYU. The speeches (1981 to 1991) are from events including NYU graduations, Board of Trustee and Senate University meetings, and other public appearances. Speech files often contain final copy and drafts; notes; and informational memos containing event location, time/date, and background. Three of these speech files also include video recordings. Unless otherwise stated, the speeches were delivered by Brademas. Yearly NYU graduation ceremony files often contain detailed schedules, event programs, and speeches from all presenters. This series also contains op-ed pieces, articles, and memos written by Brademas. Presidential greetings and letters for use by various NYU publications are also in this series.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this series is restricted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains chronological correspondence files dating from 1981 to 1990, with the bulk from 1983 to 1986. Topics include communications with staff and faculty; discussions with politicians and heads of state; relations with potential and existing donors; and parents requesting intervention for admission.
